intro: Rubus tereticaulis microgene curtiglandulosus, commonly known as the narrowleaf blackberry, is a species of brambles native to the western United States. It is characterized by its slender, thornless stems and small, elliptical leaves with finely serrated edges. The plant produces clusters of small, dark purple to black berries that are typically edible. It thrives in a variety of soil types but prefers well-drained, loamy soils. Botanically, it is notable for its complex floral structure and its role in local ecosystems as a food source for wildlife.
